title: A YouTuber Built The CyberRoadster Tesla Won‚Äôt Make
description: It‚Äôs not a actually a truck or a roadster, but who cares when this YouTuber‚Äôs transformation of a wrecked Model 3 looks this good?
author: Chris Chilton
excerpt: It‚Äôs not a actually a truck or a roadster, but who cares when this YouTuber‚Äôs transformation of a wrecked Model 3 looks this good?
text: It‚Äôs not a actually a truck or a roadster, but who cares when this YouTuber‚Äôs transformation of a wrecked Model 3 looks this good? 3 hours ago by Chris Chilton A YouTuber is building a ‚ÄúCyberRoadster‚Äù coupe from an accident-damaged Tesla sedan. The doors are the only body panels left from the donor car, a black Model 3 Performance. Originally scheduled for a 2020 launch, the real Tesla Roadster is now delayed until 2025 or 2026. We‚Äôre now four years past the original scheduled launch date for the Tesla Roadster and there‚Äôs no sign of it making a debut until 2025 at the earliest. But rather than wait patiently, one YouTuber built his own, and from what we can see he‚Äôs done an awesome job. David Andreyev calls his home-built creation the CyberRoadster, though it‚Äôs neither a truck nor a convertible. But now dressed in 12 coats of candy red paint, it looks incredible all the same. His starting point was a crash-damaged black Model 3 Performance, though there‚Äôs very little left of the external bodywork. Related: Musk Suggests Tesla Roadster Isn‚Äôt A Priority, But Thanks ‚ÄúLong-Suffering Deposit Holders‚Äù The roof has been chopped in traditional hot rod style, and every body panel bar the two front doors appears to have been built from scratch or heavily modified. Compared with the concept version of Tesla‚Äôs real Roadster, Andreyev‚Äôs creation is far more muscular, with a blockier front end and a Dodge Charger Daytona-style hood complemented by wide sill extensions. It also has a transverse light bar in a nod to the Cybertruck, something not seen on Tesla‚Äôs other vehicles. And there‚Äôs a definite Italian supercar feel to the back end thanks to the combination of a wide black panel splitting the bumper from the rear bodywork and a fake ‚Äúengine‚Äù visible through a glass panel in the rear deck. Andreyev says he still needs to finish the interior, but claims it shouldn‚Äôt take long. It certainly won‚Äôt be as complicated as building the CyberRoadster‚Äôs exterior ‚Äì the rear quarter panels alone took several months to complete and went through more than 30 iterations. Sure, there are some elements you might change ‚Äì sticking with the sedan‚Äôs front doors means they look too narrow, for instance, and the visibility must be terrible ‚Äì but considering this was all achieved by one man in his garage without a million-dollar budget, it‚Äôs amazing what he‚Äôs accomplished. And it gives us hope that creative people will always want to modify cars, no matter what‚Äôs under the hood in the years to come. Images: David Andreyev/@cyber_hooligan
html:
It‚Äôs not a actually a truck or a roadster, but who cares when this YouTuber‚Äôs transformation of a wrecked Model 3 looks this good?

3 hours ago

by Chris Chilton

  • A YouTuber is building a ‚ÄúCyberRoadster‚Äù coupe from an accident-damaged Tesla sedan.
  • The doors are the only body panels left from the donor car, a black Model 3 Performance.
  • Originally scheduled for a 2020 launch, the real Tesla Roadster is now delayed until 2025 or 2026.

We‚Äôre now four years past the original scheduled launch date for the Tesla Roadster and there‚Äôs no sign of it making a debut until 2025 at the earliest. But rather than wait patiently, one YouTuber built his own, and from what we can see he‚Äôs done an awesome job.

David Andreyev calls his home-built creation the CyberRoadster, though it‚Äôs neither a truck nor a convertible. But now dressed in 12 coats of candy red paint, it looks incredible all the same. His starting point was a crash-damaged black Model 3 Performance, though there‚Äôs very little left of the external bodywork.

Related: Musk Suggests Tesla Roadster Isn‚Äôt A Priority, But Thanks ‚ÄúLong-Suffering Deposit Holders‚Äù

The roof has been chopped in traditional hot rod style, and every body panel bar the two front doors appears to have been built from scratch or heavily modified. Compared with the concept version of Tesla‚Äôs real Roadster, Andreyev‚Äôs creation is far more muscular, with a blockier front end and a Dodge Charger Daytona-style hood complemented by wide sill extensions.

It also has a transverse light bar in a nod to the Cybertruck, something not seen on Tesla‚Äôs other vehicles. And there‚Äôs a definite Italian supercar feel to the back end thanks to the combination of a wide black panel splitting the bumper from the rear bodywork and a fake ‚Äúengine‚Äù visible through a glass panel in the rear deck.

Andreyev says he still needs to finish the interior, but claims it shouldn‚Äôt take long. It certainly won‚Äôt be as complicated as building the CyberRoadster‚Äôs exterior ‚Äì the rear quarter panels alone took several months to complete and went through more than 30 iterations.

Sure, there are some elements you might change ‚Äì sticking with the sedan‚Äôs front doors means they look too narrow, for instance, and the visibility must be terrible ‚Äì but considering this was all achieved by one man in his garage without a million-dollar budget, it‚Äôs amazing what he‚Äôs accomplished. And it gives us hope that creative people will always want to modify cars, no matter what‚Äôs under the hood in the years to come.

Images: David Andreyev/@cyber_hooligan
